questions.text: Antiparasitic action of Metronidazole on E. histolytica is via :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Metronidazole acts against anaerobic protozoa like Entamoeba histolytica by disrupting their redox balance. E. histolytica lacks the conventional glutathione-glutathione reductase system found in most eukaryotic cells, and instead depends on the thioredoxin reductase system to counter oxidative stress.

  • Metronidazole undergoes reduction within the parasite to generate nitro radicals, which damage DNA and proteins.
  • These radicals disrupt the thioredoxin-dependent antioxidant defenses, leading to oxidative damage and cell death.
  • Hence, the mechanism of action is through inhibition of the thioredoxin reductase system.

Explanation of other options:

Disruption of cell wall (Option B): This is typical of β-lactams and glycopeptides, not metronidazole.

Inhibition of protein synthesis (Option C): Applies to aminoglycosides, tetracyclines, etc., not metronidazole.

Binding to 50S subunit (Option D): Seen with macrolides and chloramphenicol, unrelated to metronidazole.

Key Takeaways:

  • Metronidazole kills histolytica by inhibiting the thioredoxin reductase system.
  • This generates toxic radicals, leading to DNA and protein damage.
  • histolytica, Giardia, and Trichomonas are all sensitive to metronidazole.

choices.text: Lack of a clinical response in 3-5 days.
To prevent rupture of left lobe abscesses into the pericardium.

questions.text: Following are indications of aspiration of liver abscesses, Except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aspiration of liver abscesses is typically reserved for specific clinical scenarios and is not routinely done based on size alone, even in large abscesses up to 10 cm.

The main indications for aspiration include:

  • Multiple lesions where differentiation from pyogenic abscess is needed.
  • Lack of clinical response after 3-5 days of medical therapy.
  • To prevent rupture, especially left lobe abscesses that pose a risk of pericardial involvement.

However, studies show no added benefit of aspiration in accelerating resolution of large abscesses that are otherwise responding clinically to treatment.

Explanation of other options:

Multiple lesions (Option A): True indication helps rule out pyogenic etiology.

Lack of clinical response in 3-5 days (Option C): True suggests need for intervention.

To prevent rupture of left lobe abscesses into the pericardium (Option D): True anatomically important reason for early aspiration.

Key Takeaways:

  • Aspiration is not routinely indicated based on abscess size
  • Indications include no response, risk of rupture, and diagnostic uncertainty.
  • Left lobe abscesses carry higher rupture risk into the pericardium.

questions.text: The most common extra intestinal manifestation of Amebiasis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common extraintestinal manifestation of Entamoeba histolytica infection is the formation of an amebic liver abscess. After penetrating the intestinal mucosa, the trophozoites enter the portal circulation and preferentially localize in the liver, leading to abscess formation.

  • Patients typically present with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and hepatomegaly.
  • This complication is seen both in endemic areas and in travelers returning from those regions 95% of whom develop liver abscesses within 5 months of exposure.
  • Young patients tend to have more acute presentations (<10 days), while older adults may show more insidious symptoms.

Explanation of other options:

Painful genital ulcers (Option A): Can rarely occur due to direct extension from colonic or perianal disease, but they are very uncommon.

Cerebral involvement (Option B): Represents a very rare complication of hematogenous dissemination and occurs in severe or untreated cases.

Pleuropulmo involvement (Option C): May result from direct rupture of a liver abscess into the pleural or pericardial space, but this is a complication, not the primary extraintestinal manifestation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Liver abscess is the most frequent extraintestinal site of histolytica infection.
  • Occurs via portal vein spread from the colon.
  • Prompt recognition and treatment prevent rupture or dissemination.

questions.text: The most common complication of Amebiasis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common complication of amebic liver abscess is pleuropulmonary involvement, occurring in approximately 20–30% of cases. This typically results from direct extension or rupture of the hepatic abscess, especially when located in the right lobe, through the diaphragm into the pleural space or lungs.

  • Manifestations include right-sided pleural effusion, empyema, or lung abscess.
  • Patients may present with cough, dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and occasionally expectoration of anchovy-paste-like sputum.

Explanation of other options:

Rupture into the pericardium (Option A): A rare but life-threatening complication, usually from left lobe abscesses. Though serious, it is less common than pleuropulmonary spread.

Acute abdomen (Option B): May occur from intestinal perforation, but is not the most frequent complication.

Hepatobronchial fistula (Option C): A rare complication of long-standing pleuropulmonary involvement, but not as common as general pleuropulmonary extension.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pleuropulmonary extension is the most common complication of amebic liver abscess.
  • Occurs via direct diaphragmatic extension, especially from right lobe abscesses.
  • Can present with respiratory symptoms and mimic primary pulmonary disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old village man presented to the OPD with complaints of RUQ pain and fever for 2 weeks. He started developing a productive cough in the last 2 days. On investigating, chest X-ray showed normal lung fields and there was altered echogenicity in the liver in the right lobe on the USG, confirming the diagnosis of amoebiasis. What could be the possible cause of cough in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's symptoms of right upper quadrant pain, fever, and ultrasound findings of a right lobe liver lesionconfirm amoebic liver abscess. The new onset of productive cough, in the context of a hepatic lesion in the right lobe, raises suspicion for a hepato-bronchial fistula, a rare but recognized complication.

  • This occurs when the abscess erodes through the diaphragm and forms a communication with the bronchial tree.
  • It often presents with cough productive of anchovy-sauce-like sputum, and patients may have minimal findings on chest imaging early in the process.
  • It has a favorable prognosis when diagnosed early and managed appropriately.

Explanation of other options:

Abdominal TB (Option A): Would not typically present with liver abscess and acute productive cough; less likely in this clinical setting.

Infective pleural effusion (Option B): Would typically show abnormalities on chest X-ray, which is reported as normalhere.

CHF (Option D): Would not explain RUQ pain and fever, nor is it associated with liver abscess or productive cough of this nature.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hepato-bronchial fistula is a classic pulmonary complication of right lobe amoebic liver abscess.
  • Presents with productive cough, sometimes with anchovy-paste sputum.
  • Early chest imaging may be normal, making clinical suspicion essential.

questions.text: Tissue invading stage of Amebiasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The tissue-invading stage of Entamoeba histolytica is the trophozoite form.

  • The infective stage is the mature quadrinucleate cyst, which is ingested via contaminated food or water.
  • After ingestion, excystation occurs in the small intestine, releasing trophozoites.
  • These motile trophozoites invade the colonic mucosa, causing ulceration, and may spread via the portal circulation to extraintestinal sites like the liver.
  • Trophozoites are responsible for tissue destruction, dysentery, and abscess formation.

Explanation of other options:

Cyst (Option A): Infective form, not the invasive stage.

Egg (Option B): Not applicable; Entamoeba does not produce eggs (a feature of helminths).

Adult larva (Option C): Also irrelevant; this terminology applies to helminths, not protozoa.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cyst = infective stage
  • Trophozoite = tissue-invading stage
  • Trophozoites cause ulcers, dysentery, and liver abscesses

questions.text: Investigation of choice for Acanthamoeba infection is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The investigation of choice for Acanthamoeba infection, particularly in granulomatous amebic encephalitis (GAE) or keratitis, is the demonstration of trophozoites and cysts in wet mounts of biopsy specimens.

  • Brain or corneal biopsy samples examined under microscopy can reveal Acanthamoeba trophozoites and cysts.
  • Wet mount is a rapid method to identify the organisms.
  • Culture on non-nutrient agar with coli may also support growth, and immunofluorescence staining improves sensitivity.

Explanation of other options:

Lumbar puncture (Option B): May aid in diagnosis, but is often contraindicated due to raised intracranial pressurein CNS infections.

CT (Option C): May show hypodense lesions or ring-enhancing lesions, but findings are nonspecific and not diagnostic.

Blood culture (Option D): Not useful, as Acanthamoeba does not grow in routine blood culture media.

Key Takeaways:

  • Wet mount from biopsy specimen is the gold standard for diagnosis.
  • CSF analysis and imaging are adjuncts but not definitive.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by visualizing trophozoites or cysts

questions.text: In Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL), What are the dominant cells?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL), the most common inflammatory cells seen in skin lesions are lymphocytes, which dominate the dermal infiltrate.

  • PKDL is a cutaneous manifestation that follows treated visceral leishmaniasis, especially with Leishmania donovani.
  • Skin lesions can range from hypopigmented macules to nodular lesions, and histopathologically show dense lymphocytic infiltrates, often with histiocytes and plasma cells.
  • Epithelioid cells may be present in up to half of cases, sometimes forming granulomas, but they are not the predominant cell type.

Explanation of other options:

Klebsiella pneumoniae (Option B): This is a bacterium, not a cell type, and is irrelevant to the histopathology of PKDL.

Plasma cells (Option C): Present, but not dominant  usually seen alongside lymphocytes.

Epithelioid cells (Option D): Can be found in granulomatous areas, but only in about 50% of cases and not in predominance.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lymphocytes are the dominant cell type in PKDL skin lesions.
  • Other cells include plasma cells, histiocytes, and occasionally epithelioid granulomas.
  • PKDL occurs as a dermal sequel of visceral leishmaniasis

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of visceral leishmaniasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common clinical presentation of visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is the abrupt onset of moderate to high-grade fever, often accompanied by rigors and chills. The fever typically follows a remittent pattern, with intermittent spikes that may persist for several weeks.

  • Fever is usually the first symptom, preceding other findings like splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and weight loss.
  • The spleen becomes palpable by the second week, often massively enlarged.
  • In endemic areas, particularly the Indian subcontinent, lymphadenopathy is uncommon, unlike in Africa or Latin America.

Explanation of other options:

Myalgias (Option B): Non-specific and not a primary feature of VL.

Cutaneous lesions (Option C): Seen in cutaneous leishmaniasis, not in visceral form.

Portal hypertension and bleed (Option D): These may develop late due to hypersplenism and pancytopenia but are not the initial or most common presentation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Fever is the hallmark initial symptom of visceral leishmaniasis.
  • Splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and anemia
  • Cutaneous and portal complications are either unrelated or appear late.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of severe babesiosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In severe babesiosis, especially in elderly, splenectomized, or immunocompromised patients, the most common life-threatening complication is acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

  • Babesia microti, the protozoan parasite responsible, infects red blood cells, leading to hemolytic anemia.
  • In severe cases, inflammatory cytokines, microvascular injury, and pulmonary capillary leakage contribute to the development of ARDS.
  • ARDS often follows massive hemolysis and may present with hypoxia and diffuse pulmonary infiltrates.

Explanation of other options:

AKI (Option B): Can occur due to hemoglobinuria or hypoperfusion, but it is less common than ARDS.

ALI (Option C): Acute lung injury is part of the ARDS spectrum but ARDS is the more specific and severe diagnosis in this context.

Encephalopathy (Option D): Rare; CNS involvement is not a hallmark of babesiosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • ARDS is the most common and serious complication of severe babesiosis.
  • Other complications include severe anemia, renal failure, hepatic dysfunction, and splenic rupture.
  • High-risk groups include elderly, splenectomized, and immunosuppressed

questions.text: Only who approved malaria vaccine is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mosquirix (also known as RTS,S/AS01) is the only WHO-approved malaria vaccine as of now. It was approved in October 2021 for emergency use in children living in malaria-endemic regions of sub-Saharan Africa.

  • It targets Plasmodium falciparum, the deadliest species of malaria parasite.
  • It works by inducing immunity against the circumsporozoite protein (CSP) of the parasite.
  • Administered intramuscularly in 4 doses, starting from 5 months of age.

Explanation of other options:

Matrix-m (Option B): This is not a malaria vaccine; it's an adjuvant used in other vaccines, such as Novavax COVID-19 vaccine.

RTS,S (Option C): Technically correct, as Mosquirix is RTS,S, but Mosquirix is the approved product name.

PfSPZ (Option D): An experimental whole sporozoite vaccine under clinical trials, not yet WHO-approved.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mosquirix (RTS,S/AS01) is the first and only WHO-approved malaria vaccine.
  • Targets Plasmodium falciparum in young children in Africa.
  • Administered via intramuscular injection in 4 doses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter because she saw something moving in her mother's eye. The patient is visiting from Africa where she lives in the rainforest. The patient reports some occasional eye swelling and redness. On examination, you find a worm in the subconjunctiva see Figure .Which of the following medications is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with a classic case of loiasis, caused by the filarial nematode Loa loa, also known as the African eye worm. It is endemic to rainforest regions of Central and West Africa.

  • The adult worm can be seen migrating across the subconjunctiva, leading to transient eye symptoms.
  • Other manifestations include Calabar swellings (transient angioedema), itching, and localized pain.
  • The most effective treatment for both microfilarial and macrofilarial stages is Diethylcarbamazine (DEC), which is curative but may need multiple courses.

Explanation of other options:

Albendazole (Option A): May reduce microfilarial load but is not first-line for Loa loa. Often used in adjunctive therapy.

Ivermectin (Option C): Effective for Onchocerciasis and Strongyloides, but contraindicated in high microfilarial load of Loa loa due to risk of fatal encephalopathy.

Terbinafine (Option D): An antifungal, used for dermatophyte infections like tinea corporis, not helminths.

Key Takeaways:

  • Loiasis is treated with Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) as the drug of choice.
  • Ivermectin is contraindicated due to severe adverse effects in patients with high microfilarial loads.
  • Visual migration of the worm in the eye is diagnostic.

questions.text: What is the second most common cause of death among the parasites?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Entamoeba histolytica, the causative agent of intestinal amebiasis and amebic liver abscess, is recognized as the second leading cause of death from parasitic infections worldwide  second only to malaria.

  • It is transmitted via the fecal-oral route and is prevalent in areas with poor sanitation.
  • Severe cases can lead to fulminant colitis, toxic megacolon, perforation, and liver abscess rupture, all of which contribute to high mortality.
  • Although often asymptomatic, invasive forms are life-threatening, especially when diagnosis or treatment is delayed.

Explanation of other options:

Malaria (Option A): Correctly considered the most common cause of death among parasitic diseases globally.

Chagas Disease (Option C): Causes chronic complications like cardiomyopathy and megacolon, but has a lower mortality burden compared to amebiasis.

Visceral Leishmaniasis (Option D): Causes significant morbidity and mortality but ranks below E. histolytica in total deaths worldwide.

Key Takeaways:

  • histolytica is the second most deadly parasitic infection after malaria.
  • Severe forms include fulminant colitis and liver abscess rupture.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment are key to preventing complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the Features indicating a poor prognosis in Severe Falciparum Malaria?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In severe falciparum malaria, prognosis is determined by the presence of organ dysfunction, metabolic derangement, or high parasite burden. Features that indicate poor prognosis include:

  • Shock (Option A): Suggests severe systemic involvement and circulatory collapse.
  • Hyperventilation (Option B): Reflects underlying metabolic acidosis, often a marker of poor outcome.
  • Anuria (Option C): Indicates acute kidney injury, another severe complication with high mortality.

High-grade fever, although common, is a non-specific sign of infection and is not by itself predictive of poor outcome. It occurs in both uncomplicated and complicated malaria.

Key Takeaways:

  • Organ dysfunction (shock, anuria), acidosis, and altered consciousness indicate poor prognosis.
  • High fever is common but not a poor prognostic marker in itself.
  • Management focuses on early identification of life-threatening features.

questions.text: A 26 week pregnant woman is planning to visit a malaria endemic area. What is the best drug for malaria chemoprophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For malaria chemoprophylaxis during pregnancy, especially in regions with chloroquine-resistant Plasmodium falciparum, mefloquine is the recommended drug of choice.

  • Mefloquine is considered safe during the second and third trimesters, and although data on first-trimester exposure are limited, they are largely reassuring.
  • It is effective against multidrug-resistant strains and suitable for weekly dosing, making it practical for travelers.

Explanation of other options:

Doxycycline (Option B): Contraindicated in pregnancy due to risk of permanent teeth discoloration and inhibition of bone growth in the fetus.

Chloroquine (Option C): Safe in pregnancy but not effective in regions with chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum.

Proguanil (Option D): Can be used in combination (e.g., with atovaquone) but safety data are less robust compared to mefloquine, and it is not preferred as monotherapy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mefloquine is the preferred chemoprophylaxis in pregnant women traveling to chloroquine-resistant areas.
  • Avoid doxycycline in pregnancy due to teratogenic risks.
  • Chloroquine only useful in non-resistant areas.

questions.text: Therapeutic usage of Chloroquine is not indicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chloroquine (CQ) is used in several autoimmune and inflammatory conditions due to its immunomodulatory effects, but it is not used in the treatment of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF).

  • ARF is a post-streptococcal, immune-mediated condition best managed with anti-inflammatory drugs (like aspirin) and antibiotics to eradicate streptococci and prevent recurrence.
  • Chloroquine has no role in its treatment.

Chloroquine is therapeutically used in:

  • M: Malaria
  • R: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
  • E: Extraintestinal amebiasis
  • D: Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE)
  • L: Lepra reactions (especially Type II)
  • I: Infectious mononucleosis (for photoreactive rashes)
  • P: Photodermatoses

Mnemonic: "My RED LIP"

Explanation of other options:

Discoid Lupus (Option A): Correct  chloroquine is commonly used to treat cutaneous lupus lesions.

Lepra Reaction (Option C): Used in Type II lepra reactions (ENL) for its anti-inflammatory effects.

Infectious Mononucleosis (Option D): Used off-label for photoreactive skin manifestations.

Key Takeaways:

  • Chloroquine has wide therapeutic use in autoimmune and parasitic conditions.
  • ARF is not one of them; treatment relies on NSAIDs and antibiotics.
  • Use the mnemonic My RED LIP to recall its indications.

questions.text: Which is not the complication of Malaria in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Yellowish brown teeth are a result of tetracycline or doxycycline exposure in utero, not a direct complication of malaria. This is due to permanent staining of developing teeth when these antibiotics are used during tooth development (second and third trimesters), and it is drug-induced, not infection-related.

In contrast, malaria in pregnancy, especially falciparum malaria, leads to multiple fetal and maternal complications:

  • Low birth weight (due to placental insufficiency and maternal anemia)
  • Stillbirth (from severe anemia or placental infection)
  • Premature birth (due to inflammatory responses and placental dysfunction)

These effects are especially prominent in primigravidae in high-transmission areas.

Explanation of other options:

Low birth weight (Option A): Very common due to placental sequestration and anemia.

Stillbirth (Option B): Can result from severe placental infection or maternal complications.

Premature birth (Option C): Seen due to inflammation and maternal illness.

Key Takeaways:

  • Malaria in pregnancy leads to low birth weight, preterm delivery, and stillbirth.
  • Yellowish brown teeth are a side effect of tetracyclines, not malaria.
  • Avoid doxycycline in pregnancy due to teratogenic risks.

questions.text: Renal failure by Falciparum Malaria is not common among?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Renal failure in falciparum malaria typically results from acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to hemoglobinuria, hypotension, dehydration, or immune-mediated injury. It is a well-known and severe complication, especially in:

  • Adult males
  • Pregnant women
  • Non-pregnant adults

However, children are less likely to develop frank renal failure compared to adults. Although they may exhibit mild renal impairment, the incidence of clinically significant renal failure requiring dialysis is far lower.

  • When renal failure does occur, early initiation of dialysis or hemofiltration significantly improves survival outcomes.

Explanation of other options:

Pregnant woman (Option B): Higher risk due to increased susceptibility to severe malaria and complications like ATN.

Non-pregnant woman (Option C): Risk similar to other adults; renal complications can occur.

Adult male (Option D): Commonly affected; more likely to develop severe complications like renal failure.

Key Takeaways:

  • Renal failure from falciparum malaria is uncommon in children.
  • ATN is the typical renal lesion in adults.
  • Early renal support improves outcomes in high-risk groups.

questions.text: Which Plasmodium Species do not cause relapses?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Plasmodium knowlesi is a zoonotic malaria species that infects humans via transmission from macaque monkeys in Southeast Asia. Unlike P. vivax and P. ovale, it does not form hypnozoites in the liver dormant stages responsible for relapse.

  • Therefore, knowlesi does not cause relapses.
  • It has a 24-hour erythrocytic cycle, the shortest among Plasmodium species, and can cause rapidly progressive disease.

Explanation of other options:

P. curtisi (Option A): A species of P. ovale that does form hypnozoites and can cause relapses.

P. wallikeri (Option B): Another form of P. ovale that also causes relapses.

P. vivax (Option C): Well-known for relapse due to dormant hypnozoites in the liver.

Key Takeaways:

  • Only vivax and P. ovale (both curtisi and wallikeri) cause relapses.
  • knowlesi, like P. falciparum, does not have a hepatic dormant stage.
  • No hypnozoite = No relapse.

questions.text: A 21-year old woman living in rural Indonesia is in her third trimester of pregnancy and is found to have severe microcytic anemia with a hematocrit of only 19%. She denies vaginal bleeding but consistently has darkened stools, which are positive when tested for occult blood. Blood laboratory testing is also remarkable for eosinophilia and low serum albumin concentration. Which of the following parasitic infections is the most likely to result in this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with classic findings of chronic iron deficiency anemia microcytic anemia, dark stools positive for occult blood, low albumin, and eosinophilia  all of which strongly suggest hookworm infection, particularly in an endemic area like rural Southeast Asia.

  • Hookworms (Ancylostoma duodenale, Necator americanus) attach to the small intestinal mucosa and ingest blood, leading to chronic blood loss, iron deficiency, and hypoalbuminemia.
  • Pregnant women are especially vulnerable due to increased iron demands, making them more susceptible to severe anemia.
  • Eosinophilia is a common feature in helminthic infections due to the immune response to migrating larvae.

Explanation of other options:

Enterobiasis (Option A): Caused by Enterobius vermicularis, presents with perianal itching, not blood loss or anemia.

Amoebiasis (Option B): Caused by Entamoeba histolytica, may cause dysentery and liver abscess, but does not typically cause iron deficiency anemia or eosinophilia.

Diphyllobothrium latum (Option C): Causes megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to macrocytosis, not microcytosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hookworm infection is a leading cause of iron deficiency anemia in developing regions.
  • Presents with occult GI blood loss, eosinophilia, and hypoalbuminemia.
  • Pregnant women are at higher risk due to increased iron demands.

questions.text: A 40-year old woman from southern India has severe lymphedema of her right lower extremity and left breast. She has had this condition for at least a decade, and it is a common condition in her rural village. She now has difficulty going to work and is extremely embarrassed by her deformity to the point at which she tries not to venture outside of her home except at night. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This woman’s presentation of chronic, disfiguring lymphedema of the limbs and breast, especially in a rural village in southern India, is classic for lymphatic filariasis, most commonly caused by Wuchereria bancrofti.

  • It is endemic in parts of India, and the chronic phase leads to irreversible lymphedema or elephantiasis, particularly of the legs, breasts, and genitalia.
  • The deformity leads to significant social stigma, disability, and psychological distress, as described in this case.
  • The disease progresses from recurrent lymphangitis and lymphadenitis to permanent lymphatic damage and swelling.

Explanation of other options:

Loiasis (Option B): Caused by Loa loa, produces transient, migratory Calabar swellings not chronic lymphedema.

Onchocerciasis (Option C): Known as river blindness, it affects skin and eyes, leading to dermatitis and visual loss, not lymphedema.

Dracunculiasis (Option D): Caused by Dracunculus medinensis, presents with ulceration and worm extrusion, but not with chronic swelling or lymphedema.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lymphatic filariasis causes chronic, irreversible lymphedema of limbs, breasts, and genitals.
  • Caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and transmitted by mosquitoes.
  • Other filarial infections cause transient or dermatologic symptoms not elephantiasis.

questions.text: Paragonimus is acquired by ingestion of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Paragonimus westermani, also known as the lung fluke, is acquired by eating raw or undercooked freshwater crabs or crayfish that serve as the second intermediate host.

  • After ingestion, the metacercariae excyst in the duodenum, penetrate the intestinal wall and migrate to the lungs where they form cyst-like lesions.
  • This causes chronic cough, hemoptysis, and radiographic findings that may mimic tuberculosis.

Explanation of other options:

Watercress (Option B): Associated with Fasciola hepatica, not Paragonimus.

Fresh fish meat products (Option C): Associated with Clonorchis sinensis and Diphyllobothrium latum, not Paragonimus.

All of the above (Option D): Incorrect, only crab/crayfish are linked to Paragonimus transmission.

Key Takeaways:

  • Paragonimus is acquired from undercooked crab or crayfish, not fish or plants.
  • It causes lung disease that can mimic TB.
  • Snail = first host, crab/crayfish = second host, humans = definitive host.

questions.text: Cholangiocarcinoma is associated in Southeast Asia with chronic carriage of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Opisthorchis viverrini, a liver fluke endemic to Southeast Asia, is strongly associated with the development of cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer).

  • Chronic infection causes inflammation, epithelial hyperplasia, and eventually malignant transformation of the bile duct epithelium.
  • Both viverrini and Clonorchis sinensis are classified as Group 1 carcinogens by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC).
  • This association is particularly significant in countries like Thailand and Laos, where raw freshwater fish consumption is common.

Explanation of other options:

Fasciola hepatica (Option A): Causes biliary fibrosis and cholangitis, but not associated with cancer.

Strongyloides (Option B): Causes hyperinfection syndrome, particularly in immunocompromised patients, but not linked to malignancy.

Toxoplasma (Option C): Affects CNS, eyes, and placenta, not the biliary tract.

Key Takeaways:

  • Opisthorchis viverrini is a known cause of cholangiocarcinoma.
  • Associated with chronic inflammation and biliary tract injury.
  • Fasciola, Strongyloides, and Toxoplasma are not carcinogenic.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for treating schistosomiasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Praziquantel is the drug of choice for the treatment of schistosomiasis, which is caused by Schistosoma mansoni, S. haematobium, S. japonicum, S. intercalatum, S. mekongi, and S. guineensis. It works by increasing membrane permeability to calcium, leading to parasite paralysis and death.

It is highly effective in both intestinal and urinary schistosomiasis and is the standard therapy recommended globally.

Below is the reference table from Harrison's showing the drugs of choice for major trematode (fluke) infections:

Explanation of other options:

Albendazole (Option A): Used for nematodes and cestodes like ascariasis, neurocysticercosis, but not effective against schistosomes.

Ivermectin (Option B): DOC for strongyloidiasis and onchocerciasis, not for trematodes like schistosomes.

Diethylcarbamazine (Option D): Used for filarial infections like Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, not schistosomiasis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Praziquantel is the DOC for all forms of schistosomiasis.
  • Other trematodes like Fasciola require Triclabendazole.
  • Anthelmintic drug choice depends on parasite class (nematode, trematode, cestode).

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of toxoplasmosis in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In pregnancy, the treatment of choice for toxoplasmosis depends on whether fetal infection has been confirmed:

  • Spiramycin is the drug of choice for maternal toxoplasmosis before fetal infection is confirmed (via PCR of amniotic fluid).
    • It concentrates in placental tissue, helping to reduce transmission to the fetus.
    • It is not teratogenic and is considered safe in all trimesters.

Once fetal infection is confirmed, therapy is changed to pyrimethamine + sulfadiazine + leucovorin, but pyrimethamine is avoided in the first trimester due to teratogenicity.

Explanation of other options:

Sulfadiazine (Option A): Used in combination with pyrimethamine after fetal infection is confirmed, not as monotherapy.

Sulfadiazine + Pyrimethamine (Option B): Effective regimen post-confirmation of fetal infection but contraindicated in the first trimester.

None of the above (Option D): Incorrect because spiramycin is clearly indicated.

Key Takeaways:

  • Spiramycin is the DOC for maternal toxoplasmosis in pregnancy before fetal infection.
  • Pyrimethamine + sulfadiazine is reserved for confirmed fetal infection.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment reduce vertical transmission.
